commitResults.messageBody: Added greet(), bidFarewell() methods for Duke to say hi and bye
Added docs for Duke class, greet(), bidFarewell() and makeSeparation() methods

commitResults.messageTitle: Completed implementation of Level 1. Greet, Echo, Exit
commitResults.messageBody: Added takeCommand() and makeResponse() methods.

Duke now can store tasks
added array to store task
modified makeResponse() to handle 'list' command
added '\t' escape sequence to Duke's responses

commitResults.messageTitle: Completed implementation of Level 3. Mark as Done
commitResults.messageBody:
Added Task class
Added checkForCommand() method to check for commands. Improved command handling in makeResponse() method

commitResults.messageTitle: Completed implementation of Level 4. ToDOs, Events, Deadlines
commitResults.messageBody:
Added ToDo, Event and Deadline classes, subclasses of Task class
Added CreareTask() method to handle the creation of correct Task subclasses
Implemented basic error handling using print statements
Added semi automated test-cases, to be tested using runtest.bat

Added DukeException, DukeUnknownInputException and DukeBadInstructionFormatException
Duke now handles wrong commands and wrong format for tasks

Added delete function to Duke.
Added DukeMemory class, which acts as a task manager.
Added enum for commands like "mark", "delete" etc.
Updated Automated Testing.

If-else statements are harder to read than switch statements. There
are no javadocs for Commands enum.

Better coding practices from CS2103T can be followed.

Using switch statements make code more readable than if-else.

Let's convert if-else statements to switch statements when possible.

Switch statements are easier to read than if-else statements.

Level 6 Duke does not have 'save' feature. Level 7 increment
requires 'save' feature.

Let's.
* add FileManager class to keep track of duke.txt, the 'hard disk'
* update automated testing runtest.bat and input to support testing
this new feature

commitResults.messageTitle: Add feature to understand date and times
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke uses String to store 'by' of deadlines or 'from' and 'to' of
events.

This is not utilizing available package LocalDateTime to display
dates and times better.

Let's,
* Use LocalDateTime for subclasses of Task that need to store a
date and time instead of Strings.
* Display date time in 'dd LLL yyyy HHmm' format.
* Get user date time input in 'dd/MM/yyyy HHmm' format.

commitResults.messageTitle: Merge Save feature with date and time feature
commitResults.messageBody:
Loading Tasks from memory: Deadline and Event date time format in
duke.txt not compatible with constructor parameter format.

Stored date time format is compatible with constructor date time
format.

Let's,
* Add variable to store acceptable date time format strings
* Update automated testing scripts

All classes are in the same directory and the main duke file is very
long as a lot of logic that can be abstracted to other classes are
in there.

Better OOP practices need to be followed and the main duke class
needs to be more readable and less cluttered.

Lets,
* Encapsulate logic behind parsing user input and printing to output
into the Ui and Parser classes
* Encapsulate all commands using Command classes and move away from
simple enumerations
* Package and refactor files into better organized directories.
* Update the automated testing scripts

commitResults.messageTitle: Integrate gradle, JUnit and package duke as a JAR file
commitResults.messageBody:
We do not have build automation or JUnit testing.

Week 3 iP task 4 requires the addition of gradle, Junit testing and
having a duke.jar.

Let's,
* Merge the gradle fork available
* Add simple JUnit tests for TaskList and Deadline
* Create a Jar file (make it available on new release page)

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix style errors and add javadocs to main classes
commitResults.messageBody:
Not all classes have javadocs or match the code style.

We know its good practice to do so.

Let's,
* Add javadocs to all non-test classes
* Correct the wrong style formats

Style conventions are not fully adhered to.

It is good practice to follow the given coding standard.

Let's,
* Strictly follow the coding standard and pass gradle's checkstyles

Duke does not have a 'find' function.

Level 9 requires us to add it.

Let's,
* Add a 'find' function to Duke
* Add a FindCommand class to encapsulate this

# Conflicts:
#	src/main/java/duke/tasklist/TaskList.java

commitResults.messageTitle: Implement rough but functional Duke with GUI
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's,
* Integrate javafx for a GUI.
* Add relevant classes like DialogBox.
* Make Duke.java compatible with javafx launcher
* Make Duke the entrypoint of the javafx launcher

commitResults.messageTitle: Implement rough but functional Duke with GUI
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's,
* Integrate javafx for a GUI.
* Add relevant classes like DialogBox.
* Make Duke.java compatible with javafx launcher
* Make Duke the entrypoint of the javafx launcher

(cherry picked from commit 0215319e4d6a7c11f31f5f852968c0bb6f8d9d4a)

commitResults.messageTitle: Add GUI to Duke and fix minor issues
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke is only works on CLI, minimizing user satisfaction.

Duke may seem unappealing to some users.

Let's,
* Integrate Javafx to give Duke a GUI
* Use fxml files to make code follow OOP principles better
* Update minor details like comments based on PR review feedback

commitResults.messageTitle: Add assert to check certain commands and fix 'bye' bug
commitResults.messageBody:
We assume the full command inputted by the user is correct when
instantiating commands like todo, event and deadline. 'bye' also
does not close Duke.

We should explicitly check the invariant that the full command
corresponds to the correct command type.

Let's,
*Add assert checks for todo, deadline, event and bye commands
*Make the GUI close upon the 'bye' command
Add assert to check certain commands and fix 'bye' bug

Maintaining good code quality is important throughout development.

Certain new features from the previous few pushes do not follow good
code quality.

Let's,
*Reduce copy pasting in Ui and only declare fixed messages once,
avoiding 'magic' strings
*SLAP harder in task commands by abstracting the process of getting
task descriptions, event from, event to and deadline by in the
command class
Improve code quality

commitResults.messageTitle: Add remind feature, abstract LocalDateTime methods, improve code quality
commitResults.messageBody:
Duke cannot remind a user if a task is due on the current day. There
are also magic symbols to split storage text and a lot of methods
using LocalDateTime is in the Task class.

We want to add a new feature called remind and we should encapsulate
LocalDateTime in a more relevant class.

Let's,
*Add remind command that reminds user on events and deadlines due
today
*Refactor LocalDateTime methods to a new Time class
*Make minor changes to improve code quality like removing magic
symbols
Add remind feature, abstract LocalDateTime methods, improve code

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix minor code quality and check style errors
Improve GUI and fix mimpr Ui bugs
commitResults.messageBody:
Let's,
* Add colour, font, background colour and coloured textboxes
* Make profile pictures clipped to a circle
* Make Duke app window resizeable
* Add missing 'space' to unmark and mark index out of range error
message
* Remove wrongly formatted sad face in error messages

Let's,
* Update README.md
* Make a basic user guide

commitResults.messageTitle: Fix minor bugs in Ui.png name and README
Fix minor bugs in Ui.png naming and github visible readme

commitResults.messageBody: Branch a assertions
Branch a code quality
